name: My Unexpected Six-Month Break
My Unexpected Six-Month Break

content.html: After finishing a crazy race to finish my manuscript for Running the Asset ahead of schedule, my body gave out, forcing me to take an extended break.
content.value: After finishing a crazy race to finish my manuscript for Running the Asset ahead of schedule, my body gave out, forcing me to take an extended break.

content.html:
Hi there!

Thanks for coming back to the blog after my unexpected six-month break. It‚Äôs crazy to think it‚Äôs been that long since my last writing-related post!

So, you‚Äôre probably wondering what the hell happened. Especially after everything was going so well. A quick recap of what was going so great: I‚Äôd finished writing Running the Asset way ahead of schedule, racking up insane daily word counts, and then I decided to dive straight into the editing stage.

Yeah, you‚Äôve probably guessed what happened. If you followed my daily updates, you could probably see it coming.

Me, nope‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶ even if I did, I ignored it.

The Dreaded Burnout

Until I burnt out hard, even though I didn‚Äôt want to admit it at the time. I‚Äôd pushed myself so hard during the final stretch of writing and editing that my body gave out. I had a major Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) flare-up that made it impossible for me to even look at my planner, let alone do any work. But, eventually, the flare-up subsided‚Ä¶

But I still couldn‚Äôt get the work done. No matter how the guilt of not getting any writing done ate at me, I couldn‚Äôt make myself write. Instead, I sank all my energies (the same level of energy I‚Äôd put into finishing the manuscript early) into the household things I‚Äôd put off or ignored when I‚Äôd been focused on writing. I was convinced that once I‚Äôd caught up on all the household chores I‚Äôd been neglecting, I‚Äôd be itching to get back to work.

But that didn‚Äôt exactly go according to plan.

The Worst Flu Ever and Etsy

My body had other ideas‚Ä¶ enter the flu. I‚Äôd never felt so terrible in my life as I did during that bout of the flu. I decided that the best way to get better, faster, was to keep myself occupied for the month I was sick. I‚Äôve always enjoyed using Canva (a graphic design app from Australia), so I played around with that‚Ä¶ and might have gone a bit daft with it.

When I say ‚Äúa bit daft,‚Äù I mean full-on obsessed to the point that I had enough designs to open an Etsy shop. And, yes, I did open an Etsy shop‚Äîthe sole aim is to raise some funds to pay for Running the Asset‚Äôs editing.

My Timing Sucks!

As much as I enjoyed working on the shop, my characters were calling to me.

I‚Äôd ask Siri to play music, and then bam, songs from the soundtrack to Running the Asset would fill the room. Teasing me. (Yes, I‚Äôve got a soundtrack for the book. And, yes, it‚Äôs fucking awesome‚Äîif you love hard rock, metal, and a wee dash of alternative rock.) Or, I‚Äôd be looking for some lost notebook and find Adam‚Äôs character sheet staring back at me.

That was it.

I was finally mentally ready to get back to work.

I‚Äôd had enough time away from the story.

That‚Äôs what I‚Äôd needed, wasn‚Äôt it?

But, my timing being what it is, I had to put the desire to write on hold for a few days as we were going on our first trip away in three years. It was just a few days away, to the beach town of Kirkcaldy (Kirkcaudy in Scots). I welcomed the changI‚Äôdf scenery and promised myself that I‚Äôd do nothing work related‚Äîno writing, designing, or shop admin‚Äîand just enjoy a complete break.

It was great. For the first time in years, I could leave work behind and focus on enjoying the scenery and the sound of the waves lapping the shore as we walked for miles each day.

The Worstestest Flu Ever

And then, just as I thought things were finally turning around, I got hit with the flu again. This time it was the kind that made that ‚Äòworst flu ever‚Äô seem like a mild cold. I lost all sense of smell and taste, and my hearing went with them. No amount of testing said that it was COVID, but I‚Äôve avoided being near others.

I‚Äôm happy to report that I‚Äôm on my way out of it now. I can taste things with a strong flavour, and if something is shoved under my nose, I can smell it in one nostril, and my hearing is starting to clear up.

The Break is Over. I‚Äôm Ready!

During this time, I‚Äôve come to believe the universe was telling me to slow down and take a physical break. That just changing where I unleash my crazy laser focus isn‚Äôt how to take a rest. So, instead of diving into a full schedule of rewrites and edits, I‚Äôm easing back into working on Running the Asset‚Äìallowing myself a bit longer to get each stage done and taking days off to physically and mentally relax and recharge.

Thank You

I‚Äôm going to end this post with a big thank you for your messages asking how I was while I was AWOL. They really meant a lot, and hopefully, I‚Äôve responded to you all personally by now, but if I haven‚Äôt (I‚Äôm sorry), thank you for your messages.

I‚Äôll be back with a new post on Monday. Remember to hit the follow button to get updates and to see my posts in your Reader feed.

Until then, have a great day!
Susan.

Yeah, you‚Äôve probably guessed what happened. If you followed my daily updates, you could probably see it coming.



Me, nope‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶ even if I did, I ignored it.

Until I burnt out hard, even though I didn‚Äôt want to admit it at the time. I‚Äôd pushed myself so hard during the final stretch of writing and editing that my body gave out. My Timing Sucks!

I‚Äôd ask Siri to play music, and then bam, songs from the soundtrack to Running the Asset would fill the room. Teasing me. (Yes, I‚Äôve got a soundtrack for the book. And, yes, it‚Äôs fucking awesome‚Äîif you love hard rock, metal, and a wee dash of alternative rock.) I‚Äôd had enough time away from the story.

But, my timing being what it is, I had to put the desire to write on hold for a few days as we were going on our first trip away in three years. It was just a few days away, to the beach town of Kirkcaldy (Kirkcaudy in Scots). I welcomed the changI‚Äôdf scenery and promised myself that I‚Äôd do nothing work related‚Äîno writing, designing, or shop admin‚Äîand just enjoy a complete break.








 Kirkcaldy beach, Scotland. A great place for a break.  Kirkcaldy beach, Scotland. A great place for a break. 



 Take a break and watch the sunrise  Take a break and watch the sunrise 



    



    This is December‚Ä¶ in Scotland!




It was great. For the first time in years, I could leave work behind and focus on enjoying the scenery and the sound of the waves lapping the shore as we walked for miles each day.









The Worstestest Flu Ever



And then, just as I thought things were finally turning around, I got hit with the flu again. This time it was the kind that made that ‚Äòworst flu ever‚Äô seem like a mild cold. I lost all sense of smell and taste, and my hearing went with them. No amount of testing said that it was COVID, but I‚Äôve avoided being near others.



I‚Äôm happy to report that I‚Äôm on my way out of it now. I can taste things with a strong flavour, and if something is shoved under my nose, I can smell it in one nostril, and my hearing is starting to clear up.



The Break is Over. I‚Äôm Ready!



During this time, I‚Äôve come to believe the universe was telling me to slow down and take a physical break. That just changing where I unleash my crazy laser focus isn‚Äôt how to take a rest. So, instead of diving into a full schedule of rewrites and edits, I‚Äôm easing back into working on Running the Asset‚Äìallowing myself a bit longer to get each stage done and taking days off to physically and mentally relax and recharge.



Thank You



I‚Äôm going to end this post with a big thank you for your messages asking how I was while I was AWOL. They really meant a lot, and hopefully, I‚Äôve responded to you all personally by now, but if I haven‚Äôt (I‚Äôm sorry), thank you for your messages.



I‚Äôll be back with a new post on Monday. Remember to hit the follow button to get updates and to see my posts in your Reader feed.



Until then, have a great day!Susan.

content.html:
Wishing everyone a happy new year filled with love, laughter, and all the things that bring you joy. Here‚Äôs to a brighter future!

See you all very soon!

Susan

content.html:
I thought that it was about time to get back to the site. Instead of jumping back in with one of my regular post series‚ÄìI‚Äôm still taking a break from work at the moment‚ÄìI wanted to do something a wee bittie different.

Even though I‚Äôm more comfortable aiming down range than I am down a camera lens, I‚Äôve decided to step out of my comfort zone and take part in this week‚Äôs Lens Artist challenge‚Äìguest hosted by my beloved, Jez.

In Jez‚Äôs Seeing Double post he challenges us to share our photos of reflections. Other than reflections of me in museum displays üòÇ, I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd have many. But, I was wrong. Yay!
content.value:
I thought that it was about time to get back to the site. Instead of jumping back in with one of my regular post series‚ÄìI‚Äôm still taking a break from work at the moment‚ÄìI wanted to do something a wee bittie different.



Even though I‚Äôm more comfortable aiming down range than I am down a camera lens, I‚Äôve decided to step out of my comfort zone and take part in this week‚Äôs Lens Artist challenge‚Äìguest hosted by my beloved, Jez.



In Jez‚Äôs Seeing Double post he challenges us to share our photos of reflections. Other than reflections of me in museum displays üòÇ, I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd have many. But, I was wrong. Yay!




 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 1. Tree reflected in a multi-faceted mirror



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 2. Ferns reflected in the camera lens and Jez‚Äôs watch



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 3. Canalside reflected in my glasses and the canal



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 4. Double the bikes; double the trees



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 5. Auchinstarry Marina



    6. Me reflected in a museum case ü§™



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 7. The Armadillo reflected in the River Clyde



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 8. Full circle at the top of the Falkirk Wheel



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 9. Longgannet Power Station reflected in the Forth



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 10. Forth Ports, Grangemouth reflected in the Forth



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 11. Building reflected in Brothock Water, Arbroath



 Image gallery image  Image gallery image 12. Sunrise reflected in a metal railing

content.html:
According to Scottish Twitter, it‚Äôs #GiesAScotsPhraseDay (give us a Scots phrase) today! And, luckily for me, it‚Äôs a Things in Scots post day!

As I can‚Äôt think of a complete Scots phrase in Running the Asset (off the top of my), other than stick the heid oan, I‚Äôll share this one with you.

content.html:
Hiya üëã

Last week I shared that I set up a timetable to help me focus on my edits. I also mentioned that I‚Äôd probably not stick to it. My prediction was correct, but not to the extent I‚Äôd internally feared. Yay!

The timetable I set up is a fantasy. The fact I actually stuck to it 70-ish% of the time is shocking to me. The times I did stick to it, I saw a considerable increase in my focus on the job‚Äìand a boost in my overall productivity. ü§ì
